Innovators in Action
Up & Down for Everyone!
Ready, Set, Learn!
You will be able to:
• Design a seesaw that allows children who use wheelchairs to play safely.
• Explore and describe how force and motion affect how the seesaw moves. • Use addition and subtraction up to 20 to balance different weights on each side.
• Measure and compare objects to help create a balanced design. • Choose strong and safe materials for building their seesaw. • Observe how pushes and pulls make the seesaw move.
• Use words like fast, slow, up, and down to describe movement.
37

Adam: “The seesaw is hard to use. How can we make it easier for Khaled?”
Laila: “Maybe we can change something so we don’t have to push so much.”
Khaled: “Can we find a way to help it go up and down, even if one side is heavier?”
Ms. Sara: “Great ideas! What can we do to help it move more easily and safely for everyone?”
Adam: “We can make the middle part stronger or change how it moves.”
Laila: “And we can make sure there’s a big, safe space so Khaled can use it too.”
Ms. Sara: “Wonderful thinking! Let’s work together to build a seesaw that’s fun and safe for all kids!”

Hey flriends let’s wrap up!
• A force is what we use to push or pull the seesaw. • When we pull one side down, the other side goes up.
• When we push down, we make the seesaw move the other way. • The seesaw also moves differently depending on how heavy the objects are—heavier objects need more force to lift!
